EDITORIAL.
T other colleges it is the custom for either the Junior or Senior Class
to leave behind it some remembrance. Such a custom has never been
;: :V VVVVVVV:: .
44
established at Hopkins, although in the past there have been two or
40
0
1 i'4,1 three classes that have presented something to the Trophy Room.
V'
•*
Hopkins is so young that it cannot be expected to have many tradi✓ .
tions
and customs, but we most certainly ought to have at least one
✓ 1.custom.
The Senior Class is now discussing the matter of leaving a
•*
V
• VVVVVVVVIOVY
suitable memorial of the class, but as yet it has not decided what that
r
shall be. It has been suggested to the class that they erect a sunOil V lif'd
dial in the Botanical Gardens which are building at Homewood.
This would be a very beautiful gift, and could be prettily arranged in the gardens. It
would be partly surrounded by a semi-circular hedge, where later could be placed a marble
bench of the same shape.
Another plan that has been proposed is to give a panel of the fence which is to be built
around the athletic field. This needs more explanation. The University has plans for this
fence, which shall be of the following style: It shall have a solid base, about three feet high,
and a column every twenty feet. This part is to be of brick with marble trimmings. Between
the columns is to be an iron picket-fence. This style of fence will make the grounds more
open, and will be much prettier than a solid wall. To prevent outsiders from seeing the
games, there will be a tall hedge inside the fence. Now it has been suggested that the Senior
Class build a section of this fence, from column to column, and build in the fence a tablet
containing the class numerals. The exact cost has not been estimated, but it is said that it
would not exceed one hundred and fifty dollars. Surely the class can afford that amount.
We might suggest that instead of the Senior Class making this present it should be done in the
Junior year, when the class-expenses are not so heavy as at the time of graduation.
If some class should start this custom it would be followed by all the classes yet to
come, and the scheme would probably be aided by some of the classes that have gone before.
At this rate it would not be long before we had a handsome fence around our athletic field,
and, therefore, this matter should be taken up immediately by either the present Senior or
Junior Class.

hidden under the big Mexican saddles, nibbled
the scanty grass before the door.
Harry walked across the road and entered
the hotel. Inside, ten or a dozen men stood
talking loudly at the bar. One of these,
whom his companions called Bill, especially
attracted Harry's attention.
.He was an enormous fellow with high
leather boots, tight buckskin breeches and a
blue flannel shrit, around the neck of which
a red bandana was loosely knotted. His face,
half-hidden under a broad sombrero, was particularly malevolent. His small, pig-like eyes
were set close together, and a long, deep scar
started at his ear and lost itself in his heavy,
black moustache. His make-up was anything
but pleasing.
As Harry entered, the ruffian was saying to
the bartender: "Set 'em up, Curly, they're
on me tonight.''
Then as he caught sight of Harry, "Come
over, stranger, an' have a drink."
Despite his protest, Harry was obliged to
take some of the fiery liquid that served for
whiskey in Campbell; then he beat a hasty
retreat to the porch.
Harry went to bed soon after supper that
night and slept like a log, for he was tired out
by his trip.

The next day was Sunday, consequently
the mine would be deserted, and Harry felt
safe in making an inspection of it. Therefore he was up before sun-rise and, having
hired a horse the night before, he began his
fifteen-mile ride to the mine.
He had gone some distance before the sun,
like a red ball of fire, began to peep over the
sun, like a red ball of fire, began to peep
over the Cerbat Mountains, bathing the world
in glorious sun-light. The scene before him
was magnificent. Five miles away to his
right, the mountains rose majestically, their
rugged sides hardly discernable against the
bright sun behind them. On his left, the
broad, flat prairie stretched away for miles,
until it seemed to merge with the hazy morning sky. The muffled beats of the pony's
hoofs were the only sound to break the peaceful stillness.
Just as the livery-man had said, the trail

5

ended about two miles from the mine, but the
buildings Were plainly visible from the end
of the trail. Several frame shanties, clustered
closely together, showed its location, and as
Harry approached, he saw that the place was
deserted.
As he dismounted from his pony and prepared to descend the shaft, his heart beat
furiously.
"Suppose McGregor is honest; what if the
mine is worthless," he thought, as he peered
down the black mouth of the shaft. "I
would be practically penniless; not even a
profession to fall back upon."
With these thoughts racing through his
brain, Harry almost feared to find out the
truth; but with an effort he pulled himself together and began the descent.
Soon he reach a cross-cut, and as he held
his lantern close to the wall, he shouted
aloud.
"GOLD! GOLD! Oh it's true, it's true?"
Then as his inspection progressed, he found
a new vein, lately uncovered, even richer than
the first.
"Poor Dad." he muttered, "he was easy
indeed. There's enough here to make three
people wealthy. I reckon Mr. McGregor's
days around the Three Star Mine are numbered."
With a light heart Harry ascnded the
shaft, and, mounting his pony, rode slowly
back to Campbell.
When he entered the hotel, he asked the
bartender where he could find Mr. William
McGregor, of the Three Star Mine.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

"Huh! Don't talk in riddles, sonny. What
do you mean?"
"I mean, McGregor, that your services are
no longer needed around the Three Star
Mine."
"Thanks for the information, sonny, but
would you mind telling me who you are?" and
McGregor smiled pleasantly.
"Did it ever occur to you that, although
too ill to come himself, James Bronson might
have a son? Well, I am that son."
"Mr. Bronson, I am very glad to know you,
and I deeply sympathize with you in your
recent trouble."
"My recent trouble? What do you mean?"
"Your father's death."
"You knew of it."
"I saw it in a New York paper I happened
to pick up."
"I don't need your sympathy, McGregor,
and I repeat that your services are no longer
wanted."
"I fail to see, young man, what you have
to do with it," and McGregor's eyes flashed
threateningly.
"I happen to own the mine, that's all."
"Why, me boy, I bought that mine two
months ago, from your father."
"You lie, McGregor, and you know it.
Don't try to bluff me that way; I have a clear
and,— No, you don't, either!"
Harry had whipped out his revolver and
covered McGregor, for the latter's hand had
begun to slide slowly back toward his hip
pocket,
"I give you twelve hours to get out of the
State; if you are not gone by that time, I
shall turn you over to the sheriff. You may
have what you stole from poor old dad, though
you don't deserve it. Now, go!"
W. B. W.

PHI BETA KAPPA.
The annual banquet of Maryland Alpha
Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa was held in
McCoy Hall, on the evening of Saturday,
May 16th. The h all w a s handsomely
decorated with palms, and the initials of the
society were outlined in electric lights. The
speaker of the evening was Professor Albion
W. Small, of the University of Chicago, who
made one of the finest addresses ever given
before the local society. Among the large
attendance were the seventeen initiates, including the five members of the senior class,
Chesney, Gorton, Mann, McCauley, and
Loos.

NEWS ITEMS.
President Remsen was present at the conference of Governors at the White House held
during the present month.
Mr. Edwin E. Slosson, a member of the
board of the New York Independent, spent
several days at the University last week,
gathering material for an article on the twelve
leading colleges in the United States. The
article will probably be published in the
Independent in the course of the coming year.

Very artistic programs have been made for the

On Tuesday afternoon, there will be the

As is customary, the Seniors will put in a
week of gaiety between the examinations and

week, which is composed of Mr. Kelly,
Mr. Frank, Mr. Ridgely, and Mr. Bridgman,
have made very extensive plans for the occasion. Dates are being made for the entire time.
Since most, if not all, of the Seniors, will
finish their examinations by Thursday at noon,
the committee are making arrangements for a
trip down the bay that afternoon. They will
leave about three o'clock, arriving at their
destination in time for dinner. There they
will spend the night, and will have a rousing
good time, for this class has demonstrated on
many occasions that it is capable of doing so.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

ITAIi3711
OUR LACROSSE CHAMPIONS.
GEE—HEE !
(,1 -11A !!
GEE—HA, HA, IIA !
TEAM!

TEAM !

TEAM !

Let's all give three rousing cheers for the
best team that ever wore the Black and Blue,
the Lacrosse Team of 1908.
They won the collegiate lacrosse championship of the United States by defeating Swarthmore, 4 to 3. They won the local championship by defeating Mount Washingeon, 7 to 4,
and they only lost the American collegiate
championship to the University of Toronto in
a game that the Canucks had to sweat blood
to win, 9 to 6.
In addition to these honors our team has
had the great honor of having been invited to
attend the Olympian games in England, and
contest with the champion college teams of
England, Canada and Australia for the world's
lacrosse championship.
The game with Mount Washington brought
out what was probably the best play of the
season. The game started at a lightning pace,
and in the first few minutes' play Mount
Washington scored the first tally. Both sides
fought hard for fifteen minutes before the
Mountaineers tallied again. After this goal,
however, the Black and Blue attack steadied
down, and after a pretty bit of team work,
Clary slipped the ball past Briscoe, the Mount
Washington goal tend.

•

In the second half our fellows, with the
memory of the Swarthmore game lodged
firmly in their minds, started out to do things.
The Mountaineers just could not resist the
hurricane style of play of the Black and Blue
mid-field and attack, and when the smoke
cleared at the end of the half the score stood
7 to 4 in our favor.
The entire team played as a unit in this
game, and every man deserves full credit.
Clary showed himself especially clever in
shooting goals, and should be a valuable man
next year. Much credit is also due to that
mid-field quartet—Chesney, Lowndes, Breyer
and Cline—for they maintained a fast pace
from start to finish and easily winded their
opponents.
The Toronto game was undoubtedly the
hardest fought of the season. Although our
team was defeated, it died fighting hard, and
our fellows deserve all the honor imaginable
for the game struggle they put up. It is safe
to say that Toronto is the only College team
in America that could have downed the team
that Hopkins put on the field.
The work of the Hopkins defense was excellent, Walter Blanck, Frank Williams, Meyer
and Captain Harry Schmeisser playing as
they never played before. On the attack,
Chesney, Clary, Lowndes, Frank and Breyer
played with all the energy that was in them,
and had it not been for the excellent work of
Captain Areans at goal for Toronto the victory
would have been ours.

THE MEET WITH VIRGINIA.
In the final event of the season our track
team was defeated by the University of Virginia, the score standing 75 to 21 points in
their favor.
Virginia has this year the best track team
that it ever turned out. This is amply shown
in the fact that in this meet their athletes
equalled one world's record and smashed three
South Atlantic records. Rector equalled the
world's record in the 100-yard dash by making the distance in 9 3-5 seconds. The same
sprinter ran the 220 in 21 4-5, a new South
Atlantic record. New marks were also made
in the 120 and 220-yard hurdles.
Captain Brenton ran a fine race in the
mile, making the distance in 4: 37 3-5. This
breaks the Hopkins record of 4: 47 1-5 which
was held by G. M. Griffith, '06.

Shot-Put—First, Seville, Virginia; second,
Cecil, V irgi n i a. Distance, 34 feet 5%
inches.
Hammer Throw—First, Bryant, Hopkins;
second, Miller, Hopkins. Distance, 116 feet
6 inches.

ATHLETIC NOTES.
Swarthmore defeated Stevens Institute at
lacrosse, May 16th, by the score of 8 to 2. In
the first half, Swarthmore scored three points
and made numerous attempts at goal, while
Stevens at no time seriously threatened the
Quakers' goal. Stevens played fast at the
beginning of the second half and registered
her two points, but could not keep up the
pace. Ridgway shot six of Swarthmore's
goals.

Summaries:
100-Yard Dash—First, Rector, Virginia;
second, Ashby, Virginia. Time,9 3-5 seconds.

of the track team for next year.

EDITORIAL.
T other colleges it is the custom for either the Junior or Senior Class
to leave behind it some remembrance. Such a custom has never been
;: :V VVVVVVV:: .
44
established at Hopkins, although in the past there have been two or
40
0
1 i'4,1 three classes that have presented something to the Trophy Room.
V'
•*
Hopkins is so young that it cannot be expected to have many tradi✓ .
tions
and customs, but we most certainly ought to have at least one
✓ 1.custom.
The Senior Class is now discussing the matter of leaving a
•*
V
• VVVVVVVVIOVY
suitable memorial of the class, but as yet it has not decided what that
r
shall be. It has been suggested to the class that they erect a sunOil V lif'd
dial in the Botanical Gardens which are building at Homewood.
This would be a very beautiful gift, and could be prettily arranged in the gardens. It
would be partly surrounded by a semi-circular hedge, where later could be placed a marble
bench of the same shape.
Another plan that has been proposed is to give a panel of the fence which is to be built
around the athletic field. This needs more explanation. The University has plans for this
fence, which shall be of the following style: It shall have a solid base, about three feet high,
and a column every twenty feet. This part is to be of brick with marble trimmings. Between
the columns is to be an iron picket-fence. This style of fence will make the grounds more
open, and will be much prettier than a solid wall. To prevent outsiders from seeing the
games, there will be a tall hedge inside the fence. Now it has been suggested that the Senior
Class build a section of this fence, from column to column, and build in the fence a tablet
containing the class numerals. The exact cost has not been estimated, but it is said that it
would not exceed one hundred and fifty dollars. Surely the class can afford that amount.
We might suggest that instead of the Senior Class making this present it should be done in the
Junior year, when the class-expenses are not so heavy as at the time of graduation.
If some class should start this custom it would be followed by all the classes yet to
come, and the scheme would probably be aided by some of the classes that have gone before.
At this rate it would not be long before we had a handsome fence around our athletic field,
and, therefore, this matter should be taken up immediately by either the present Senior or
Junior Class.

THE NEWS-LETTh,R.

hidden under the big Mexican saddles, nibbled

Harry walked across the road and entered
the hotel. Inside, ten or a dozen men stood
talking loudly at the bar. One of these,
whom his companions called Bill, especially
attracted Harry's attention.
.He was an enormous fellow with high
leather boots, tight buckskin breeches and a
blue flannel shrit, around the neck of which
a red bandana was loosely knotted. His face,
half-hidden under a broad sombrero, was particularly malevolent. His small, pig-like eyes
were set close together, and a long, deep scar
started at his ear and lost itself in his heavy,
black moustache. His make-up was anything
but pleasing.
As Harry entered, the ruffian was saying to
the bartender: "Set 'em up, Curly, they're
on me tonight.''
Then as he caught sight of Harry, "Come
over, stranger, an' have a drink."
Despite his protest, Harry was obliged to
take some of the fiery liquid that served for
whiskey in Campbell; then he beat a hasty
retreat to the porch.
Harry went to bed soon after supper that
night and slept like a log, for he was tired out
by his trip.

The next day was Sunday, consequently
the mine would be deserted, and Harry felt
safe in making an inspection of it. Therefore he was up before sun-rise and, having
hired a horse the night before, he began his
fifteen-mile ride to the mine.
He had gone some distance before the sun,
like a red ball of fire, began to peep over the
sun, like a red ball of fire, began to peep
over the Cerbat Mountains, bathing the world
in glorious sun-light. The scene before him
was magnificent. Five miles away to his
right, the mountains rose majestically, their
rugged sides hardly discernable against the
bright sun behind them. On his left, the
broad, flat prairie stretched away for miles,
until it seemed to merge with the hazy morning sky. The muffled beats of the pony's
hoofs were the only sound to break the peaceful stillness.
Just as the livery-man had said, the trail

5

ended about two miles from the mine, but the
buildings Were plainly visible from the end
of the trail. Several frame shanties, clustered
closely together, showed its location, and as
Harry approached, he saw that the place was
deserted.
As he dismounted from his pony and prepared to descend the shaft, his heart beat
furiously.
"Suppose McGregor is honest; what if the
mine is worthless," he thought, as he peered
down the black mouth of the shaft. "I
would be practically penniless; not even a
profession to fall back upon."
With these thoughts racing through his
brain, Harry almost feared to find out the
truth; but with an effort he pulled himself together and began the descent.
Soon he reach a cross-cut, and as he held
his lantern close to the wall, he shouted
aloud.
"GOLD! GOLD! Oh it's true, it's true?"
Then as his inspection progressed, he found
a new vein, lately uncovered, even richer than
the first.
"Poor Dad." he muttered, "he was easy
indeed. There's enough here to make three
people wealthy. I reckon Mr. McGregor's
days around the Three Star Mine are numbered."
With a light heart Harry ascnded the
shaft, and, mounting his pony, rode slowly
back to Campbell.
When he entered the hotel, he asked the
bartender where he could find Mr. William
McGregor, of the Three Star Mine.
"There he sits on the porch, sir."
.his name's Bill."

"Sure, Bill McGregor, don't you see?"
"Thanks" said Harry, and walked out to
where Bill sat basking in the sun.
"Is this Mr. McGregor?" he said, addressing Bill.
"That's my name, stranger."
"Well, I have something of importance to
tell you; would you mind coming to my
room?"
Bill rose lazily and followed Harry inside.
When the door of the room was safely closed,
Harry said:
"Don't you think you are playing a rather
risky game, McGregor?"

6

THE NEWS-LETTER.

"Huh! Don't talk in riddles, sonny. What
do you mean?"
"I mean, McGregor, that your services are
no longer needed around the Three Star
Mine."
"Thanks for the information, sonny, but
would you mind telling me who you are?" and
McGregor smiled pleasantly.
"Did it ever occur to you that, although
too ill to come himself, James Bronson might
have a son? Well, I am that son."
"Mr. Bronson, I am very glad to know you,
and I deeply sympathize with you in your
recent trouble."
"My recent trouble? What do you mean?"
"Your father's death."
"You knew of it."
"I saw it in a New York paper I happened
to pick up."
"I don't need your sympathy, McGregor,
and I repeat that your services are no longer
wanted."
"I fail to see, young man, what you have
to do with it," and McGregor's eyes flashed
threateningly.
"I happen to own the mine, that's all."
"Why, me boy, I bought that mine two
months ago, from your father."
"You lie, McGregor, and you know it.
Don't try to bluff me that way; I have a clear
and,— No, you don't, either!"
Harry had whipped out his revolver and
covered McGregor, for the latter's hand had
begun to slide slowly back toward his hip
pocket,
"I give you twelve hours to get out of the
State; if you are not gone by that time, I
shall turn you over to the sheriff. You may
have what you stole from poor old dad, though
you don't deserve it. Now, go!"

PHI BETA KAPPA.
The annual banquet of Maryland Alpha
Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa was held in
McCoy Hall, on the evening of Saturday,
May 16th. The h all w a s handsomely
decorated with palms, and the initials of the
society were outlined in electric lights. The
speaker of the evening was Professor Albion
W. Small, of the University of Chicago, who
made one of the finest addresses ever given
before the local society. Among the large
attendance were the seventeen initiates, including the five members of the senior class,
Chesney, Gorton, Mann, McCauley, and
Loos.

NEWS ITEMS.
President Remsen was present at the conference of Governors at the White House held
during the present month.
Mr. Edwin E. Slosson, a member of the
board of the New York Independent, spent
several days at the University last week,
gathering material for an article on the twelve
leading colleges in the United States. The
article will probably be published in the
Independent in the course of the coming year.

for this feature, and the dance will probably

Very artistic programs have been made for the

On Tuesday afternoon, there will be the
Commencement Exercises at the Academy of
Music. These Exercises will be followed by
the Faculty Reception at McCoy Hall that
night. This brings to a close the many
festivities of Senior Week.

As is customary, the Seniors will put in a
week of gaiety between the examinations and
Commencement. The committee on Senior
week, which is composed of Mr. Kelly,
Mr. Frank, Mr. Ridgely, and Mr. Bridgman,
have made very extensive plans for the occasion. Dates are being made for the entire time.
Since most, if not all, of the Seniors, will
finish their examinations by Thursday at noon,
the committee are making arrangements for a
trip down the bay that afternoon. They will
leave about three o'clock, arriving at their
destination in time for dinner. There they
will spend the night, and will have a rousing
good time, for this class has demonstrated on
many occasions that it is capable of doing so.

ITAIi3711
OUR LACROSSE CHAMPIONS.
GEE—HEE !
(,1 -11A !!
GEE—HA, HA, IIA !
TEAM!

TEAM !

TEAM !

Let's all give three rousing cheers for the
best team that ever wore the Black and Blue,
the Lacrosse Team of 1908.
They won the collegiate lacrosse championship of the United States by defeating Swarthmore, 4 to 3. They won the local championship by defeating Mount Washingeon, 7 to 4,
and they only lost the American collegiate
championship to the University of Toronto in
a game that the Canucks had to sweat blood
to win, 9 to 6.
In addition to these honors our team has
had the great honor of having been invited to
attend the Olympian games in England, and
contest with the champion college teams of
England, Canada and Australia for the world's
lacrosse championship.
The game with Mount Washington brought
out what was probably the best play of the
season. The game started at a lightning pace,
and in the first few minutes' play Mount
Washington scored the first tally. Both sides
fought hard for fifteen minutes before the
Mountaineers tallied again. After this goal,
however, the Black and Blue attack steadied
down, and after a pretty bit of team work,
Clary slipped the ball past Briscoe, the Mount
Washington goal tend.

•

In the second half our fellows, with the
memory of the Swarthmore game lodged
firmly in their minds, started out to do things.
The Mountaineers just could not resist the
hurricane style of play of the Black and Blue
mid-field and attack, and when the smoke
cleared at the end of the half the score stood
7 to 4 in our favor.
The entire team played as a unit in this
game, and every man deserves full credit.
Clary showed himself especially clever in
shooting goals, and should be a valuable man
next year. Much credit is also due to that
mid-field quartet—Chesney, Lowndes, Breyer
and Cline—for they maintained a fast pace
from start to finish and easily winded their
opponents.
The Toronto game was undoubtedly the
hardest fought of the season. Although our
team was defeated, it died fighting hard, and
our fellows deserve all the honor imaginable
for the game struggle they put up. It is safe
to say that Toronto is the only College team
in America that could have downed the team
that Hopkins put on the field.
The work of the Hopkins defense was excellent, Walter Blanck, Frank Williams, Meyer
and Captain Harry Schmeisser playing as
they never played before. On the attack,
Chesney, Clary, Lowndes, Frank and Breyer
played with all the energy that was in them,
and had it not been for the excellent work of
Captain Areans at goal for Toronto the victory
would have been ours.

THE MEET WITH VIRGINIA.
In the final event of the season our track
team was defeated by the University of Virginia, the score standing 75 to 21 points in
their favor.
Virginia has this year the best track team
that it ever turned out. This is amply shown
in the fact that in this meet their athletes
equalled one world's record and smashed three
South Atlantic records. Rector equalled the
world's record in the 100-yard dash by making the distance in 9 3-5 seconds. The same
sprinter ran the 220 in 21 4-5, a new South
Atlantic record. New marks were also made
in the 120 and 220-yard hurdles.
Captain Brenton ran a fine race in the
mile, making the distance in 4: 37 3-5. This
breaks the Hopkins record of 4: 47 1-5 which
was held by G. M. Griffith, '06.

Shot-Put—First, Seville, Virginia; second,
Cecil, V irgi n i a. Distance, 34 feet 5%
inches.

second, Miller, Hopkins. Distance, 116 feet

ATHLETIC NOTES.
Swarthmore defeated Stevens Institute at
lacrosse, May 16th, by the score of 8 to 2. In
the first half, Swarthmore scored three points
and made numerous attempts at goal, while
Stevens at no time seriously threatened the
Quakers' goal. Stevens played fast at the
beginning of the second half and registered
her two points, but could not keep up the
pace. Ridgway shot six of Swarthmore's
goals.

second, Ashby, Virginia. Time,9 3-5 seconds.
